Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story: I sat at the dinner table, half-listening as my family tossed around ideas for the weekend. My sister wanted to go hiking, my brother suggested a movie marathon, and my parents just wanted us all together. I could feel their eyes on me, waiting for my input, hoping I’d be part of whatever we decided. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the product team’s brainstorming session was coming up next sprint. Attendance was technically optional, but I knew how much it mattered—being there meant having a say in the new features, showing initiative, and building relationships with other teams. I could already imagine the subtle disappointment if I skipped it, the missed chance to contribute. My family’s laughter pulled me back, and I felt a knot in my stomach. I wanted to be present for them, to join in and not be the sibling who always had “work stuff.” But I also didn’t want to let my team down or miss out on shaping the project. The two worlds tugged at me, each expecting my presence, each unwilling to let go.
